title: Using Cryogenic Electron Tomography (CryoET) to Determine Binding Curves in Bacteria Microcompartments
content: Bacteria Microcompartments (BMCs) are pseudo-organelles comprised of a highly organized, permeable protein shell which self-assembles around components of specific enzymatic pathways. Carboxysomes are specialized BMCs known for their role in carbon fixation through the sequestering of Rubisco along with additional factors. Rubisco, the most abundant enzyme on earth and the protein responsible for carbon fixation in plants and algae, has low selectivity for its substrate CO2 and has a slow enzymatic rate, resulting in an inefficient metabolic pathway. The use of BMCs in cyanobacteria and many chemoautotrophs have enhanced carbon fixation. Within the carboxysome, Rubisco has been observed at a range of concentrations and with either a pseudo-lattice of fibrils or a more liquid-like assembly (Fig. 1). We have developed a processing and particle analysis pipeline which converts tomography-derived particle positions into calculated binding curves, and determined the equilibrium polymerization constant (Kpoly) through a modeling approach consistent with in situ constraints such as non-independent binding interactions and physical boundaries (Fig. 2). This novel approach offers a powerful tool to evaluate both in vitro and potentially in vivo biomolecular interactions.
